reviewText:
Hands down one of my favourite games on Steam and I have far too many ;)!

I loved the first iteration of Van Helsing and this just builds on it in so many positive ways.

I can understand people saying the skill tree is a little random, but in reality, with a little thought it's quite intuitive.

There's much more to the game than just hacking and slashing, the tower defense game is definitely one of the coolest examples, I can only hope and wait for them to release it on mobile :P. You have your own secret lair, send out commanders on missions and more.

If you like ARPG's/Hackn'Slash with a little more meat to them in terms of extra features, like a great story, amazing atmosphere and environments, witty banter between you and your companions, many classic references, tons of humour and hands down one of the best soundtracks in a game, do yourself a favour and buy this for the ridiculously low price it's at. There are only minor downsides to the game and they really are only minor.

Seriously good job to the devs, hope they continue this series!

reviewText:
UPDATE 2: I've decided to change my review. While having to wait a week to complete the game, as my save file was fixed by the developers, they did indeed fix it. They've also patched one of the problems I mentioned and are working on patching the other. The point is neocoregames is actively trying to support their games and I have to commend them for the effort. The fact is, this game is so good that it is easy to hold it to the standards of a AAA game, and frankly, it should be. There is so much to love about this game (I can't speak for the other two), that if these wrinkles are ironed out, I could see a lot more people taking a chance on an unknown Hungarian talent. I finally finished the story and I was not disappointed.

UPDATE: IMPORTANT - 27 hours in and I encountered a bug where a quest NPC does not appear. I cannot progress further. I cannot finish the game. This is a known issue. Google revealed multiple threads dealing with the same issue. Going to steam for a refund. 27 hours gone on a game I can't finish. Seriously.

I'm not downvotimg this game. I chose thumbs down because honestly, I couldn't recommend it to anyone in good faith. There is SO much potential here, but Neocoregames as a developer have decided to exploit there games rather than finish them. These games are just not finished.

Look, I love the story. I love the humor, the art, the music, the loot system, everything. It is the perfect hack and slash game, but these Hungarians are more interested in the short term. They want to make a quick buck and move onto the next thing. I don't know who owns the company, but chances are they aren't a gamer and more of an entrepreneur. Each new game or DLC means new clothes, or house, or cars for them. It's the only thing that explain the horrible ♥♥♥♥ing mess these games degrade into

First, there was no native controller support. Then, they tacked it on post development and its atrocious. Menus are clunky to navigate, features are just missing. You can't read any flavor text or descriptions. There are tower defense levels, but you'll later realize YOU CAN'T even reach the most important towers using a controller.

There are weird visuals on the screen when using a controller. Certain menus can crash your game (search for skills crash, merchant crash, or rune crash).

Point is, I want to love this game so much. There are so many funny moments and the gameplay could've been top notch, but there's no ignoring the problems. Every hour invested in this game is tempting disappointment. It's like dating someone you don't trust. You haven't caught them cheating, but you know you're risking having your heart broken. Stay for love, or leave for your own sanity. I've finally chosen sanity.

Ciao Van helsing.

reviewText:
Summary
Not Recommended because there are better alternatives on the market, and even if you have already played them, this game is mostly mediocre and does many things poorly. The developer is also very slow or just reluctant to fix the game's bugs (BIG red flag). The writing and characters may be the only saving graces, as actual gameplay is unimpressive, even boring.

The Bad
The combat is really boring and character management is a chore. The UI is ugly and unrefined, even (or especially) at high resolutions and levels of detail. The game's DX11 support remains hopelessly broken, and the game looks dated. There is good detail in the environment and, to a lesser extent, the characters, but neither really come alive; there is no flair to the action, no spice in the surroundings, and definitely not enough variety to raise interest. There are also odd lapses in the finishing touches, like subtitles getting cut off, jaggies and tearing out of nowhere, some actions look like they're missing animations or frames (bad transitions between movements, attacks, etc.), and the environment's colour scheme quickly fades into shades of grey.

The game does run well in DX9 - you can crank up the detail and effects even on low-spec cards - but it all looks dreary and unimpressive due to an apparent lack of inspiration and polish, and clunky mechanics get in the way a lot. This is Bad for a supposed Action RPG. This is more in the style of old top-down RPGs than modern ARPGs.

The Good
Copying and improving the pet system from Torchlight is a definite plus. Even if the loot system is classic in style, Katarina makes management and vendor sales a breeze.

I really like the VO and dialogue for Van Helsing and Katarina, and the storyline and characters appear to be the strong suit of the game. Too bad the focus is on combat and not questing and characters, so the writing does not get to shine much outside of cutscenes. The other VO varies in quality (the Main Ally is amateur quality, almost a joke), but the writing seems to stay solid - at least at the start.

There are good attempts to vary the gameplay by involving allied units, building, et cetera, but it's too bland in execution. Nice try though.

I sort of like the focus on just three character classes, but they feel like the devs just wanted to artificially extend game hours: it's the same hack-and-slash scuffle three times over, and the visual and mechanical variety is, again, a little uninspired.

The Alternatives
So what would I recommend instead?

Path of Exile http://store.steampowered.com/app/238960/ Free to play and works much better. Not broken either. Diablo players will be right at home. The only downsides are that the bosses are weak and the storyline over much too soon. There's also no character development (but that's no surprise). It's a grinder like Diablos 1 and 2 (and 3), but very enjoyable to play - and F2P (all paid content is cosmetics, pets, etc. and does not negatively affect gameplay or market mechanics)! You can also play solo or with friends, depending on if you want more Story or Action.

Victor Van Hel--, I mean, Victor Vran http://store.steampowered.com/app/345180/ Does a much better job of the whole vampire/monster hunter gig. The writing and characters are good, the combat is fun, and skills and loot have refreshing twists to them. The Narrator is entertaining, and makes up for the lack of a companion like Katarina.

Diablo 3 is cautiously recommended. It's pricey and has its foibles, but if you use Battle.net anyway and just want to hack things apart, it's as decent as Blizzard creations get - very well polished and pleasant to play, plus the universe might be familiar to you already.

And that's just the ARPGs that come to mind that I have played. There are more that I haven't, and a whole library of other entertaining and immersive RPG titles, both classic and new, that you can explore, and often very affordably so - try GOG.com if it's not on Steam, or if you like your games without DRM ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.

reviewText:
Pros:
- Graphics
- Voice acting
- Soundtrack

Cons:
- Everything else

Long version:
I was a great fan of the first game but unfortunately can't recommend this one. Not because it's more of the same (which it is, with some minor changes rather than improvements), that's what I expected. It's because even at casual difficulty the game is ridiculously hard from some point on due to an ever increasing number of over-powerful, infinitely-breeding enemies and there is nothing else in the game that would make it even slightly interesting. I believe that even an ARPG game should have at least a trivial story to it (like the first game did), but here there is basically no story at all. The merest scraps of some would-be-storytelling are hopelessly drowned in a constant flood of enemies. So the whole game boils down to just mad clicking, watching graphical effects and doing the same things over and over again. And to listening to dialogues between Van Helsing and Lady Katarina, of course, but even those begin to be a bit worn out after a while because there is simply nothing to reasonably talk about.

Where the first game excelled this one does a very poor job while adding nothing new. Not even the Prisoner Seven" character can save it for he is not as much mysterious as he is hollow.

I gave it a good chance

reviewText:
With experience of multiple other ARPG games, such as Path of Exile, Torchlight and the Diablo series, The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing II feels weak in comparison.

While the visuals aren't terrible, the sound effects are. Sound is a very important aspect in making the combat feel responsive and satisfying, and the game fails in this area. Hearing the same enemy type have only a single death scream means you'll get very tired of killing them - which should NEVER happen in an ARPG game. Imagine watching a movie with loads of fighting, and whenever someone dies, you hear the Wilhelm Scream. Over and over again. Not good.

You gain levels quite quickly, but each level feels insignificant. In fact, it becomes a chore to level up. This is yet another reason why playing the game does not feel good.

I haven't played the game long enough to tell how the boss fights work out, but that is because I can't bring myself to play the game any longer. I recommend you do not purchase the game unless it goes on a very heavy sale, or if there's a Humble Bundle sale with some other game you want (and this game merely comes as a sidebonus).
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Van Helsing II is an aRPG set in the mythical land of Borgovia. If you've played Grim Dawn, Diablo or Torchlight you'll be familiar with the gameplay. The game does have a unique ability system though, as you fight you gain rage which can be spent to powerup your abilities. For example lets say you're using a lightning spell, powering it up may cause enemies to be shocked, or it may increase the number of enemies hit. A powered up spell only has one charge and can be activated with the spacebar, although this becomes tedious very fast and I'd wager 99.9% of people have this set to auto cast whenever available. The game allows you to set up powerup presets so you can very much set it and forget it and the game will automatically boost the chosen ability(s) whenever you have sufficient rage. Apart from that it's your usual aRPG fare, you have a standard talent tree with forks and paths, passive abilities and stat points which allow you to customise your character further.

Throughout the game you're accompanied by your ghostly companion, Katarina. She works very much like the Torchlight pet, she can pick up items, fight for you and even be sent back to town to sell and buy which saves you the bother! She also has her own stats and talent tree, you can either build her to become stronger herself, or build her as a complete buff bot which will give you lots of powerful auras. Usefulness aside she's actually a big part of the game, and the banter between you and her is often really enjoyable, the voice acting for both Van Helsing and Katarina is top notch (the same can't be said for all the characters though!).

The story will take around 10 hours to complete which is poor, and shorter than the first game. You will finish the story around level 30 but to do scenarios you'll need to be level 57 and I couldn't work out how to level up further. Perhaps this was only intended for people who imported their character from Van Helsing I but I started a new character so was much lower level by the end of the game.

Technically the game is fine, most quests have voice acting which isn't always a given for this genre, especially from the smaller studios, and while not perfect it is pretty funny at times and there are plenty of references to other games and TV shows which I enjoyed. I will say the voice acting for Prisoner 7 is terrible, absolutely terrible and lowers the quality of the entire game by being so bad. Graphically the game is OK, it's a couple of years old and wouldn't have been anything to rave about back then, but it's fine. Performance is worse than Van Helsing I which stayed at 60fps without dips, whereas Van Helsing II will often dip in frame rate, and certain areas have issues and completely tank the frame rate. There is also a nasty bug with DX11 and Windows 8.1 where textures will not load, I suffered with this often and it made the game extremely frustrating at times.

Overall it's better than Van Helsing I, but it also introduces its own problems so I can't score it higher than 6/10, which is what I gave the first game. And once again I can only recommend buying this game while it's 75% off.

reviewText:
First of all Van Helsing II is proberbly a decent game in single player, this review is primarly based on the coop experience.

I have played 2 characters to lvl 15'ish with 2-3 friends in online coop mode and here are some of the bugs we have encountered:
* One guy in party lost ALL equipped items during a load screen.
* More than five times we encountered loss of data during loading. For instance you just leveled up and bought a ring but after you enter a ink portal sometimes levels must be assigned again and the ring you have bought is gone + loss of XP.
* At one point we dropped a pair of epic boots in the lair that could be picked up multiple times (i ended up with 10 of the same boots)
* More than five game crashes which stops the entime game for all people. (we tried different people hosting the game)
* We also experienced that the 'slow time' skill became bugged and the game speed was increasedp 3-5x times whenever he was not using the skill rendering the game pretty much unplayable. (had to recreate game)
* More often than not the 'energy bolt' skill is not visible when casting it in coop and when this happens you cannot see ranged monster attacks. (meaning you die very often without knowing why)

I bought this in the humble indie bundle for 5$ including 5 other games... if I had paid full premium for this game I would have been one unsatisfied customer.

reviewText: Van Helsing 2 continues and expands on the gameplay of its predecessor in predictable, but satisfying ways. Beginning with the ability to import a saved character from the first game, II delivers an additional thirty levels of experience, new items, skills, quests, tower defense levels, enemies, quests, and sarcastic retorts from the ghostly Lady Katerina. It is more linear then the first game, with fewer sidequests overall but more tower defense levels, and additional side mechanics that allow you to send out NPC captains to  perform offscreen missions, rewarding you with additional gold and items, and an additional pet with customizable abilities. The equipment-modding obsessed can now alter their equipment in an additional way, via stat-increasing runes. While Van Helsing II treads ground already heavily traveled, it is nonetheless an excellent Diablolike and arguably a better singleplayer experience then many other titles in the genre, due in no small part to Van Helsing's both varied and powerful skillset. My hunter-class Van Helsing was capable of dealing extrordinary damage both to single targets and in an area, but was also very survivable thanks to a lot of lifesteal. The game is significantly easier on its normal difficulty then other titles in the genre, including the first Van Helsing, but offers two additional difficulty levels beyond that along with repeatable, randomized, high-level dungeons for the discerning munchkin. I will be proceeding directly to Van Helsing III and what I hope is a thrilling conclusion to the trilogy, and I will look forward greatly to Neocore's recently announced Warhammer 40,000 ARPG, Inquisitor - Martyr.

reviewText:
+) Even better mood compared to previous series.
+) Great use of monsters from previous series.
+) Igor doesn't blow up with poison after death.
+) While in defense mission, you can gain exp from killing monsters in addition to the reward.
+) Improvement on certain skills.
+) Going up and down has become smoother but it is still bad.

-) Time to time npcs speech is outside the screen, making the game look really sloppy.
-) In last mission two musics are being played at the same time. Also sloppy.
-) Monsters and terrain are synchronized too well. It is hard to distinguish them. If they didn't move it would've been horrible.
-) Too many things. They are totally unnecessary. Rage, Defense, Army management, and Chimera.
-) Artillery support was bad. There was no hot key for it and clicking once didn't work so you end up calling it on totally wrong places. Its range is that of your character's so you'll be getting hurt while doing it as well.

reviewText:
There's a lot I like about this game, and a lot I don't like.

Pros:
Good art
Engaging companion
Occasional moments of wit

Cons:
Balance
Bugs
Corpse runs
Linear

On balance I'd probably give it a thumb-sideways rather than up or down, but despite having an expansive skill tree offering lots of customization, there are too few skill points, hotkeys, etc. to really make use of more than a few.

There are also quite a few mobs than can 1- or 2-shot even on normal difficulty even trying to kite and play defensively. I played on normal to just experiment and have fun without having to research a viable build" and yet that doesn't really work - you'll die a lot just trying to play through
